title.rendered: Create, mount, unmount, and use vfat, ext4, and xfs file systems

content.rendered:
I think all of this was mentioned in previous posts, but let’s quickly get over all of it.

Difference between vfat, ext4 and xfs

Linux supports a range of file systems, including ones used on other operating systems, such as Windows FAT and NTFS. Those may be supported by embedded developers, but normally a Linux file system like the 4 extended file system (ext4), XFS, or BTRFS will be used for most storage partitions.

vfat

This is rather not precise to put them in one group together because vfat is the most common driver for mounting FAT 16,32 and exFAT file systems.

FAT16, FAT32, and exFAT are Microsoft’s FAT file systems supported by Linux and used for formatting a drive. They have no journal, which makes them good for portable memory devices. They are default in every OS, whether it is Windows, macOS, or Linux. These file systems are great if you want to format an external drive using other OS. Nowadays, exFAT is the most appropriate version, as FAT32 is not so powerful. exFAT works with large files over 4 GB and partitions more than 8 GB, which is impossible for older (FAT32, FAT16) versions. NTFS is a newer and enhanced version of exFAT, with strengthened security and object–oriented applications.

ext4

Ext4 and Ext3 were created for compatibility reasons. The one has a built–in Ext4 file system, as Ext3, Ext2, and backwards. It was enhanced and involves fresh updates that reduced file fragmentation, made it possible to have larger files and sizes, and has a delayed allocation, which is profitable for flash memory duration. It is a basic or default version of the file system on Linux, nowadays. It had lots of updates and work put in it, so it is widely popular.

xfs

XFS was created for Linux in 2001 by Silicon Graphics. It was made for the SGI IRX OS. It doesn’t support mounted snapshots and has delayed allocation for enhancing file fragmentation, and with such features, it is similar to Ext4. XFS recommended being effective with large files, but it doesn’t work well with small files, and the performance is worse than in many other file systems. So those who are trying to find something for their service that works with large files can consider XFS as an option.

TLDR: In my eyes ext4 or NTFS always win, but there are now even more and better file system, which RHCSA doesn’t include, but I’m just going to throw bit of nerd dirt to ya.

zfs

ZFS uses a hierarchical system layout defined by location- and- conductor-specific sub-module ports each of which is restricted in the locality. Basically, it manages the physical storage of data through storage pools, which allow file systems to share disk space within the pool. When users need a larger storage pool, they add disks similar to adding memory to a computer. As users add storage space, the file systems automatically use the additional memory without the user needing to configure that memory or assign individual processes. This system limits human touch, making it not only easy to use but also highly reliable. 

ZFS also offers a built-in snapshot, which can grab a picture of stored data at a precise instant. Users find snapshots quick and easy. Snapshots take up no extra disk space in the pool at first, but as data evolves, they reference old data and thus consume some space

ZFS and EXT4 for NAS – Advantages and Disadvantages

While ext4 comes embedded on Linux, it may not be the right choice for managing your data. Consider the strengths of each system in light of your needs.  On the face of it, ZFS seems better but arrives with much higher hardware requirements to run smoothly.

Whereas EXT4 has much lower hardware running requirements but has it’s own limitations elsewhere. Let’s shine the spotlight on them both.

Using vfat formating

For vfat we use mkfs command 

mkfs.vfat /dev/sdc2

And let’s mount it to the /mnt/vfat directory

To unmount as previously did many times we do

umount /mnt/vfat

or

umount /sdc2

Using ext4 formating

We are once again going to use mkfs command

mkfs.ext4 /dev/sdc2

Mounting

mount /dev/sdc2 /mnt/ext4

Unmounting

umount /dev/sdc2 /mnt/ext4

Using xfs formating

You maybe won’t believe me, but again… it’s mkfs yes I know I’m sorry we are doing the same thing over and over but hey you need to know this!

mkfs.xfs /dev/sdc2

Mounting

mount /dev/sdc2 /mnt/xfs

Unmounting

umount /dev/sdc2 /mnt/xfs

ONE LAST IMPORTANT NOTE. To make mount changes persit past the reboot, you need to do what? Yes, that’s right the random guy on the internet, you need to add them to the /etc/fstab file. I’ve done this many times before, so I’m not gonna do it again, but it can be a good practice for ya!
